[32y/o, black female] -- I live with my parents, who have no idea how bad my depression is. They think my room is messy because I'm lazy but in reality I just don't have the strength to clean it. I also suffer with sensory issues which makes cleaning harder. My room isn't even messy anymore; it's filthy.
I mostly struggle with managing my bin, which has resulted in a rat infestation in my room. My parents don't know and I'm scared to tell them in case they get mad. But I don't know how to fix it on my own, especially since I don't do well with things like that.
Unfortunately, I need to get my room clean in a week and I just don't know what to do. I've always struggled with cleaning but my depression has made everything so much harder, so I'm very worried that it won't get done in time. 
Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Thank you

Update: Thank you so much for all of your advice. I’m happy to report that although my room isn’t spotless, it’s clean and liveable. Thank you for all of your advice and kind words
column2:
First and foremost, I commend you for reaching out for help. This is an important step and shows your strength. It's important to understand that your struggle with depression is real and acknowledging it openly as you have is critical. You are not alone in this.

The first thing to tackle is the rat infestation. This is a health risk not only to you, but also to your family. Without frightening you further, it may be worth it to consult a professional exterminator. In terms of telling your parents, you could try opening a conversation by honestly and earnestly expressing your feelings and the state of your mental health.

In terms of cleaning, try splitting it up into manageable tasks, rather than looking at it as one huge task. Small victories can serve as motivation builders. You could start by focusing on one section of your room at a time, and gradually move on to another section when you're comfortable.

Lastly, and most importantly, consider seeking professional help for your depression, if you haven't already. There are many online resources that can assist you in finding help. Don't hesitate to join support groups with people who can relate to your experience. Together, we are stronger. 

Please continue to update us on your progress. We're rooting for you!

[32y/o, black female] -- "My dad just died and my mom wants me to hang out with her all the time. I''ve never liked doing casual things with her, and I'm very independent.

I don't know how to tell her to leave me alone. The best relationship we ever had was when I lived in another state. I moved back because of my dad, but now he's gone. 

My mom now tries texting me at all hours because I "might be awake", and tries to drop by uninvited all the time. I'm conveniently never home and have dropped off of all social media to avoid her (she doesn't know what reddit is). 

Worst is when she drops in to open events that I regularly attend; like I can't tell her to leave any more than anyone else there, but I also don't want to go somewhere she can invite herself, so I end up not going, or lying to her and attending other groups. 

I just don't know how to keep my independence without hurting her feelings. I get that she's lonely, but I don't want to be her go-to person. 

Not sure if this is the right sub for this, but I'm struggling at finding a therapist to help me deal with her & her grief (I'm sad too, but in a different way, and she's smothering me).
column2:
I'm truly sorry to hear about your loss and the current emotional distress you're dealing with. It's important to remember that everyone has a unique way of processing grief, and it's crucial to create and respect personal boundaries, even in such challenging situations. Amateur advice from a stranger on the internet can only go so far, but from the description you provided, it sounds like there is a need for clear communication. 

Perhaps you could express your feelings to your mother in an open but gentle way. Let her know that you understand her need for companionship during this difficult time, but also explain your need for some independence and space to grieve. Making sure to let her know that this doesn't mean you don't care about her or her feelings, but that you need to find your balance and cope with your emotion in your way.

In regards to finding a therapist, it can be hard, especially considering everyone's needs vary. But please, don't give up. Continually seeking until you find a person who can understand and help you navigate your feelings. Online counseling might be a good option as well as you can schedule your sessions at your convenience.

Remember, during grieving periods it may be hard to see properly, but it's important to take care of yourself too. Sending you lots of strength and positivity.

Remember, it's crucial to take care of your own mental health first. If you're not okay, it's tougher to help others. Take your time and stay strong. You're not alone in this.

1. **Take Control Of Your Itinerary** - Whenever you can, have a say in where you're going, what you'll be doing, and who you'll be with. This can reduce some of your anxiety and give you a level of control that can be comforting.

2. **Preparation Is Key** - Being well-prepared can ease travel anxiety. The more you know about where you're going, what your accommodations will look like, what activities you'll participate in, the more comfortable you might feel.

4. **Pace Yourself** - Start with short trips, maybe a weekend away with friends. Gradually extend the duration as your comfort level grows.

5. **Therapy and/or Counseling** - If you find that your travel anxiety continues to persist, it might be helpful to consider working with a counselor or therapist. They can provide you with strategies to manage anxiety and help you understand its underlying causes.

Remember, overcoming anxiety is a journey in itself, it might take time and that's okay. Just take small steps and gradually proceed. Most importantly, be patient and kind to yourself.

column1: [32y/o, black female] -- I don't know when exactly it started. Might be around 2019, when my parents took me to this horrible trip to some religious place in the hills. Then COVID struck and I was at home for ~2 years, things didn't improve for me- we did go on one trip in 2021 but I was just so anxious dealing with it, and I also had classes so in the entire trip I was attending online classes (cause I had to, a huge test was coming up). My problem is that I'm anxious before the trip happens and during it I'm completely fine. It's gotten better now tho, but not completely cured. Going alone or with friends seems like a mammoth task. Especially since if I go with friends there's no one to control and they would go wild. I know I need to get over this for the future. Any tips?
column2:

It's totally okay to feel what you're feeling and it's great that things have gotten somewhat better for you. 

A couple of potential strategies you might want to consider. First, relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, visualisation, and progressive muscle relaxing can all help to reduce feelings of anxiety. Regular practice can make them more effective. They are easily available online.

Just like you said, you are fine during the trip. This indicates that your fear might be anticipated or linked to the unknown rather than the act of traveling itself. Journaling through your thoughts and experiences might help you to identify any patterns or triggers, and allow you to work through them in a safe environment.

If you haven't already, you might also consider seeking professional help. Psychologists and therapists are equipped to provide strategies and techniques to help manage anxiety.

Finally, remember the importance of baby steps. Maybe start by going on short local trips with a trusted friend or two, gradually expanding into longer distances or larger friend groups. Remember to celebrate each small victory.

Remember to be kind to yourself along the way, healing is a journey not a destination.

My partner hates my job, I just got it in January and we moved in together in February. Having to be on call for work has made me realize how “on call” I am for everything. They can’t accept the fact that I have to help out this restaurant with any problems they have on any given day. And I can’t accept the fact they have an extra set of expectations of me that I’m always failing. 

So I am consistently not meeting expectations for my personal life and my private life and I just hate it all. IT ALL FEELS LIKE WORK. 

I need help. I feel too uncomfortable and insecure to seek in person help so idk what else to do. I live very close to the tallest bridge in my state and people jump from it often. I just want to be another number for that jump list. I want my family to grieve my death for a couple days then just please forget about me. 

Secretly waiting for my parents to pass away, the I feel like I can actually kill myself without causing too much trauma for them. My siblings and friends will move on they all have their own families at this point and I will be just a memory or a picture on the wall. 

I’m just so tired of every day being work, but it’s not even my jobs fault. It only brought it to my attention.

[32y/o, black female] -- I’m sitting here at the bar I that I recently started to manage…. This was supposed to me an exciting step, a new change for a brighter future.  Every single day is work ya know? My job has crept into every aspect of my life. 

My partner hates my job, I just got it in January and we moved in together in February. Having to be on call for work has made me realize how “on call” I am for everything. They can’t accept the fact that I have to help out this restaurant with any problems they have on any given day. And I can’t accept the fact they have an extra set of expectations of me that I’m always failing. 

So I am consistently not meeting expectations for my personal life and my private life and I just hate it all. IT ALL FEELS LIKE WORK. 

I need help. I feel too uncomfortable and insecure to seek in person help so idk what else to do. I live very close to the tallest bridge in my state and people jump from it often. I just want to be another number for that jump list. I want my family to grieve my death for a couple days then just please forget about me. 

Secretly waiting for my parents to pass away, the I feel like I can actually kill myself without causing too much trauma for them. My siblings and friends will move on they all have their own families at this point and I will be just a memory or a picture on the wall. 

I’m just so tired of every day being work, but it’s not even my jobs fault. It only brought it to my attention.

[32y/o, black female] -- I have no friends aside from one from primary school who I infrequently catch up with. I really just find most people not to be worth talking to, as I find it hard to connect with many people due to my lack of shared interests and my social anxiety.

However, I often feel lonely and kinda sad especially when I see people who are having a good time with their friends.

I did actually have a weird experience making a friend just recently though, but he's way older than me so it's a bit weird to hang out in person. I noticed he had an interest in something I really liked, and we had this great chat for about 10 minutes. It flowed so smoothly, and it was super passionate. We still message each other every couple of days.

Can anyone else relate to this?
column2:
Absolutely, it's completely normal to feel this way and you're definitely not alone. It can be difficult to navigate social situations when we feel out of step with the people around us. Anxiety can certainly exacerbate that feeling of isolation, making it more challenging to connect with others. I'd like to offer a few thoughts that might be helpful for you. 

First, it's great that you're reaching out and sharing your feelings - that's a big step towards understanding what you're going through. Don't be too hard on yourself if you're not instantly clicking with everyone you meet - genuine connections take time to build. 

Remember, it's the quality of friendships, not the quantity that truly matter. You seem to have established a good connection with your new friend, and it's perfectly okay if he is older. Age doesn't determine the strength or validity of a friendship. 

Lastly, it could be beneficial to consider seeking assistance from a mental health professional to help manage your feelings of anxiety and loneliness. They can provide strategies and coping mechanisms to handle these feelings. There are also online communities and support groups available where you can connect with people who feel the same way or have gone through a similar situation.

Feel free to reach out anytime you need someone to talk to. This is a supportive community and we are here for you.
